title: Feminine Sans Serif
content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently looking for a sans serif that looks and feels more feminine than the odd helvetica / akzidenz.  
Any ideas?

Many thanks
author: dsoares1

comments.content: Helvetica and akzidenz are modernist sans-serifs. I would say humanist sans-serifs generally have a more feminine design, so you might want to search my fonts for 'humanist sans'

Typefaces don’t have gender.  
(Although there are a few constructed out of bodies/body parts…)
Parisine Plus is one that comes to mind.

Some people think that a feminine sans serif has one or more of the following characteristics: lighter weight, rounded ends, less mechanical/geometric construction, i.e. more of a handwritten feel etc. Easy to find these. Whether they are actually more feminine is a matter of opinion.  
Don

What Jasper said.  
Gender associations are not about reproductive organs.

hhp

Notwithstanding the tiresome identity politics spasms that these questions must now inescapably provoke, I would simply suggest you check out Joshua Darden’s Omnes.

[http://dardenstudio.com/typefaces/omnes\_pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063634/http:/dardenstudio.com/typefaces/omnes_pro "http://dardenstudio.com/typefaces/omnes\_pro")

Also, ironically, Mr Eaves, which I find far more feminine than The Missus.

[http://emigre.com/EF.php?fid=213](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063634/http:/emigre.com/EF.php?fid=213 "http://emigre.com/EF.php?fid=213")

Omnes in use for Girl Scouts Of America [http://dardenstudio.com/notes/fontspotting/girl-scouts-of-america](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063634/http:/dardenstudio.com/notes/fontspotting/girl-scouts-of-america "http://dardenstudio.com/notes/fontspotting/girl-scouts-of-america")  
Don
